articles.headline: An $18 Million Lesson in Handling Credit Report Errors
articles.snippet: Despite a whopping judgment against Equifax, little is going to change for those who find mistakes in their credit reports, industry observers say.
articles.abstract: Despite a whopping judgment against Equifax, little is going to change for those who find mistakes in their credit reports, industry observers say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even after sending more than 13 letters to Equifax over the course of two years, Julie Miller could not get the big credit bureau to remove a host of errors that it inserted into her credit report.

articles.headline: Surprise at TV Critics’ Gathering: DeGeneres Is to Host the Oscars
articles.snippet: At a preseason press tour, the newsmakers of the industry gave a preview of offerings.
articles.abstract: At a preseason press tour, the newsmakers of the industry gave a preview of offerings.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The producers of the Academy Awards telecast announced on Friday that they were going back to a prominent television star, Ellen DeGeneres, to host the movie industry’s biggest event, the annual Oscar ceremony.

articles.headline: Bank of New York Mellon Wins Sex Bias Case
articles.snippet: The case involved a woman who was one of 11 people — 10 of them women — laid off by Bank of New York Mellon in 2010, and it was unusual that it ended up in court.
articles.abstract: The case involved a woman who was one of 11 people — 10 of them women — laid off by Bank of New York Mellon in 2010, and it was unusual that it ended up in court.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal jury in New York decided on Friday that a woman who was one of 11 people in her division at Bank of New York Mellon laid off in 2010 was not a victim of sex discrimination. The case was unusual in that it even went to trial.

articles.headline: A Hankering for Hybrids
articles.snippet: About 298,000 hybrids, or cars that run on batteries and gasoline, have been sold this year while only 36,000 battery-powered vehicles have sold.
articles.abstract: About 298,000 hybrids, or cars that run on batteries and gasoline, have been sold this year while only 36,000 battery-powered vehicles have sold.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — When automakers rolled out their new electric cars three years ago, they had big plans. Even President Obama, in his State of the Union address in 2011, predicted there would be as many as a million of them on the nation’s roads by the middle of the decade.
articles.byline: By Jaclyn Trop and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: U.S. Cuts Take Increasing Toll on Job Growth
articles.snippet: A wave of cuts in domestic and military spending is causing government furloughs as well as job losses and curtailed hours among federal contractors.
articles.abstract: A wave of cuts in domestic and military spending is causing government furloughs as well as job losses and curtailed hours among federal contractors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The number of federal workers forced to work shorter hours soared this summer — to 199,000 in July, from 55,000 a year earlier — in a sign of the problems that federal budget policy is causing for the economy.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Catherine Rampell

articles.headline: Qaeda Messages Prompt U.S. Terror Warning
articles.snippet: Intercepted electronic communications in which senior operatives of Al Qaeda discussed attacks in the Middle East and North Africa led the United States to issue a global travel alert to its citizens, officials said.
articles.abstract: Intercepted electronic communications in which senior operatives of Al Qaeda discussed attacks in the Middle East and North Africa led the United States to issue a global travel alert to its citizens, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States intercepted electronic communications this week among senior operatives of Al Qaeda, in which the terrorists discussed attacks against American interests in the Middle East and North Africa, American officials said Friday.

articles.headline: In Complex Trading Case, Jurors Focused on Greed
articles.snippet: Jurors expressed sympathy for Fabrice Tourre, but their decision to find him liable in a toxic mortgage deal came down to what they saw as the letter of the law and concern about Wall Street greed.
articles.abstract: Jurors expressed sympathy for Fabrice Tourre, but their decision to find him liable in a toxic mortgage deal came down to what they saw as the letter of the law and concern about Wall Street greed.
articles.lead_paragraph: When nine New York residents shuffled into a cramped jury room in the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday, they were divided over Fabrice Tourre’s culpability in a toxic mortgage deal sold to investors.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig, Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Colorado Presses for Uninsured to Enroll
articles.snippet: Colorado is embracing the health care overhaul, with a vast marketing push to educate residents about it.
articles.abstract: Colorado is embracing the health care overhaul, with a vast marketing push to educate residents about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — Television commercials have already run suggesting that buying health coverage through the state’s new insurance market, Connect for Health Colorado, will feel like winning the World Series.

articles.headline: Missouri Citizens Face Obstacles to Coverage
articles.snippet: The insurance marketplace established under President Obama’s health law has no visible presence in Missouri, which stands out among states resisting the effort.
articles.abstract: The insurance marketplace established under President Obama’s health law has no visible presence in Missouri, which stands out among states resisting the effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. — Looking for the new health insurance marketplace, set to open in this state in two months, is like searching for a unicorn.

articles.headline: The Race to Build a Better Business Class
articles.snippet: Billions are being spent to pack business-class seats with engineering innovations and fancy features.
articles.abstract: Billions are being spent to pack business-class seats with engineering innovations and fancy features.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN a confidential test lab in a remote office park near the Frankfurt airport, a small Lufthansa team holed up for five years, refining one of the German airline’s most closely guarded secrets. They called it the V concept.

articles.headline: Clawbacks in Word, Not Deed
articles.snippet: Clawbacks, or money returned by an employee committing financial improprieties, are gaining support among investors and companies — though examples are rare.
articles.abstract: Clawbacks, or money returned by an employee committing financial improprieties, are gaining support among investors and companies — though examples are rare.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHAT good is a policy if it’s never enforced?

articles.headline: Iran’s President Puts New Focus on the Economy
articles.snippet: President Hassan Rouhani vowed Saturday to work with the outside world to lift the “oppressive sanctions” crippling Iran’s economy.
articles.abstract: President Hassan Rouhani vowed Saturday to work with the outside world to lift the “oppressive sanctions” crippling Iran’s economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, vowed Saturday to work with the outside world to lift the “oppressive sanctions” crippling the Iranian economy, as he received the official backing of Ayatollah Ali Khamenei at a ceremony marking the start of his presidential term.

articles.headline: Coin of Realm in China Graft: Phony Receipts
articles.snippet: Sales of counterfeit receipts, used to evade taxes and defraud employers, are becoming more sophisticated, putting considerable tax revenue at stake.
articles.abstract: Sales of counterfeit receipts, used to evade taxes and defraud employers, are becoming more sophisticated, putting considerable tax revenue at stake.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — To begin to comprehend China’s vast underground economy, one need only visit this city’s major transportation depots and watch as peddlers openly hawk fake receipts.

articles.headline: A Day’s Toil in the Suicide Bombers’ Graveyard
articles.snippet: Khwaja Naqib Ahmad lays claim to one of the toughest jobs in the Afghan capital — burying the unclaimed dead, including suicide bombers.
articles.abstract: Khwaja Naqib Ahmad lays claim to one of the toughest jobs in the Afghan capital — burying the unclaimed dead, including suicide bombers.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a city with no shortage of hard jobs, Khwaja Naqib Ahmad lays claim to one of the toughest of all — burying the unclaimed dead.

articles.headline: Other Agencies Clamor for Data N.S.A. Compiles
articles.snippet: The National Security Agency’s dominant role as the nation’s spy warehouse has prompted turf fights with other federal agencies that want to use its surveillance tools for their own investigations.
articles.abstract: The National Security Agency’s dominant role as the nation’s spy warehouse has prompted turf fights with other federal agencies that want to use its surveillance tools for their own investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency’s dominant role as the nation’s spy warehouse has spurred frequent tensions and turf fights with other federal intelligence agencies that want to use its surveillance tools for their own investigations, officials say.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Victims to Again Face Gunman in Fort Hood Trial
articles.snippet: Staff Sgt. Alonzo M. Lunsford Jr., who was shot seven times by Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan during an attack at the Fort Hood Army base in 2009, will confront his attacker during his testimony.
articles.abstract: Staff Sgt. Alonzo M. Lunsford Jr., who was shot seven times by Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan during an attack at the Fort Hood Army base in 2009, will confront his attacker during his testimony.
articles.lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — Staff Sgt. Alonzo M. Lunsford Jr. usually worked in the back of the Soldier Readiness Processing Center, giving smallpox shots to deploying and returning troops at the Fort Hood Army base here. But on Nov. 5, 2009, he was standing at the counter at the building’s entrance after 1 p.m., so that his colleagues could take a lunch break.

articles.headline: In Germany, Union Culture Clashes With Amazon’s Labor Practices
articles.snippet: Unions say the company has imported American-style business practices that stand at odds with European norms.
articles.abstract: Unions say the company has imported American-style business practices that stand at odds with European norms.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the United States, technology giants like Amazon are often celebrated as fonts of innovation and jobs.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: With 2 Hit Series Ending, a Transformed AMC Is at a Crossroads
articles.snippet: From a sleepy movie channel to an incubator of signature television, AMC is hoping to seize the moment and create new, profitable hits.
articles.abstract: From a sleepy movie channel to an incubator of signature television, AMC is hoping to seize the moment and create new, profitable hits.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was less than a decade ago that the AMC network was known solely as a vintage movie site, if it was known at all, and seemed destined to sit out the creative revolution taking place on cable television.

articles.headline: Parodying Cable News With a Talk About Race
articles.snippet: Nuance doesn’t do well on cable, so a topic as fraught as race often ends up being covered in cartoonish ways during signal events like the death of Trayvon Martin.
articles.abstract: Nuance doesn’t do well on cable, so a topic as fraught as race often ends up being covered in cartoonish ways during signal events like the death of Trayvon Martin.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night on MSNBC’s “All In,” Chris Hayes had a very direct conversation about race with the Gawker writer Cord Jefferson. Prompted by a news report of a group of young people in Huntington Beach, Calif., who looted and vandalized property, the pair lamented the lack of community leadership and suggested that acting out in that manner was a learned behavior.

articles.headline: Mom Wants You Married? So Does the State
articles.snippet: In South Korea, the government is playing a bigger role in matchmaking amid plunging birthrates and changing expectations over matrimony.
articles.abstract: In South Korea, the government is playing a bigger role in matchmaking amid plunging birthrates and changing expectations over matrimony.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — As hopeful singles at the speed dating event shifted from table to table introducing themselves, Park Chang-won, a 32-year-old firefighter, grew more and more morose.

articles.headline: In a West Bank Culture of Conflict, Boys Wield the Weapon at Hand
articles.snippet: For Palestinian young men and boys, throwing stones at Israeli soldiers and settlers is a rite of passage.
articles.abstract: For Palestinian young men and boys, throwing stones at Israeli soldiers and settlers is a rite of passage.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIT OMMAR, West Bank — Muhammad Abu Hashem, 17, was sleeping in a sleeveless undershirt when the Israeli soldiers stormed into his home here at 4 a.m. on the second Monday in July. As they led him away moments later, Muhammad’s mother rushed after with a long-sleeved shirt: they both knew it would be cold in the interrogation room.

articles.headline: The Last Temptation of Tina Brown
articles.snippet: After two and a half years of lost opportunity and revenue, Tina Brown reflected on the ill-fated merger of The Daily Beast and Newsweek.
articles.abstract: After two and a half years of lost opportunity and revenue, Tina Brown reflected on the ill-fated merger of The Daily Beast and Newsweek.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Nov. 12, 2010, Tina Brown gathered the staff of her Web site The Daily Beast in the third-floor conference room at its Chelsea offices with its commanding views of the Hudson. Brimming with the fervor she has brought to all her endeavors, she delivered some surprising news: the Web site would merge with Newsweek, a once-proud but struggling magazine brand.
articles.byline: By Leslie Kaufman and Christine Haughney

articles.headline: Boston Globe Is Another Metro Paper Gone Local
articles.snippet: The sale continues a recent trend in the struggling newspaper industry: newspapers being returned to local owners, often at bargain-basement prices.
articles.abstract: The sale continues a recent trend in the struggling newspaper industry: newspapers being returned to local owners, often at bargain-basement prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a coup for local newspaper owners when the news was announced early Saturday morning: John W. Henry, the owner of the Boston Red Sox, would purchase The Boston Globe, along with The Worcester Telegram & Gazette and other properties, from The New York Times Company for $70 million in cash in a deal that will close in a month or two. Despite the lateness of the hour, Mr. Henry, a Boston-area resident, did not contain his enthusiasm about the purchase.
articles.byline: By Christine Haughney and David Carr

articles.headline: All-You-Can-Fly Airline Plies the California Coast
articles.snippet: Surf Air runs on a pricing plan like Netflix’s: pay a membership ($500), a monthly fee ($1,650) and fly as often as you like on six-seat, single-engine turboprops.
articles.abstract: Surf Air runs on a pricing plan like Netflix’s: pay a membership ($500), a monthly fee ($1,650) and fly as often as you like on six-seat, single-engine turboprops.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — Meticulous, well-thought-out plans may be for some people, but not Wade Eyerly. At 16, he walked into the registrar’s office at the University of Central Missouri, not knowing he was supposed to have applied for admission. He walked out with a schedule of classes.
